Combining a relative threshold shift with a reduction in the ERF was associated with the largest ranges in impacts across all the methods for all cities except Valencia. Relative threshold shifts were associated with the second-largest ranges in impacts. For example, with relative threshold shifts of 50% (100%),
Δ M o r t - C C
declined from 84, 79, 72, and 77 deaths per 100,000 under no adaptation to 43 (6), 41 (9), 29 (0) and 37 (3) deaths per 100,000 with adaptation for Athens, Budapest, Milan, and Rome, respectively ( Figure 2). In terms of the difference (percent) in impacts between including and excluding adaptation ( Figure 3), these are equivalent to 49% (93%), 48% (89%), 60% (100%), and 52% (96%) respectively ( Figure 3). In five cities, a relative threshold shift of 100% resulted in
Δ M o r t - C C
reaching zero (London, Milan, Paris, Stockholm, Turin); that is to say, climate change had no effect on heat-related mortality with adaptation.
